hints_html:
The formula for the arc length of this curve on the interval from \(1 \leq x \leq 2\) is

\(\int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx.\)
hints_latex:
The formula for the arc length of this curve on the interval from
$1 \leq x \leq 2$ is

$\int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx.$
hints_raw:
The formula for the arc length of this curve on the interval from <math> 1 \leq x \leq 2 </math> is 

<math>
\int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx.
</math>
question: 2 (c)
sols_html:
Using the formula in the hint, we see that we require the derivative of the curve in question. Notice that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dx} = 2x - \frac{1}{8x}\end{aligned}\]

and so we compute the arc length to be

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx &= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + \left(2x - \frac{1}{8x} \right)^{2}} \, dx \\ &= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + 4x^{2} - \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{64x^{2}}} \, dx \\ &= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{4x^{2} + \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{64x^{2}}} \, dx \\ &= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{(2x + \frac{1}{8x})^{2}} \, dx \\ &= \int_{1}^{2}(2x + \frac{1}{8x}) \, dx \\ &= \left.(x^{2} + \frac{1}{8}\ln|x|)\right|_{1}^{2} \\ &= (2)^{2} + \frac{1}{8}\ln(2) - (1)^{2} - \frac{1}{8}\ln(1)\\ &= 3 + \frac{1}{8}\ln(2).\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Using the formula in the hint, we see that we require the derivative of the curve in question. Notice that

:<math>
\frac{dy}{dx} = 2x - \frac{1}{8x}
</math>

and so we compute the arc length to be

:<math>
\begin{align}
\int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx &= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + \left(2x - \frac{1}{8x} \right)^{2}} \, dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{1 + 4x^{2} - \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{64x^{2}}} \, dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{4x^{2} + \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{64x^{2}}} \, dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{(2x + \frac{1}{8x})^{2}} \, dx \\
&= \int_{1}^{2}(2x + \frac{1}{8x}) \, dx \\
&= \left.(x^{2} + \frac{1}{8}\ln|x|)\right|_{1}^{2} \\
&= (2)^{2} + \frac{1}{8}\ln(2) - (1)^{2} - \frac{1}{8}\ln(1)\\
&= 3 + \frac{1}{8}\ln(2).
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answer and show all your work. Simplification of the answer is not required.

Find the length of the curve

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y = x^2 - \frac{\ln x}8, \quad\text{for } 1\leq x \leq 2.\end{aligned}\]

\begin{align*}

y = x^2 - \frac{\ln x}8, \quad\text{for } 1\leq x \leq 2.
\end{align*}
